added_lines: # vim: tabstop=4 shiftwidth=4 softtabstop=4 # # Copyright 2013 OpenStack Foundation # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. # """add unique constraint to members Revision ID: e197124d4b9 Revises: 40dffbf4b549 Create Date: 2013-11-17 10:09:37.728903 """ # revision identifiers, used by Alembic. revision = 'e197124d4b9' down_revision = '40dffbf4b549' # Change to ['*'] if this migration applies to all plugins migration_for_plugins = [ 'neutron.services.loadbalancer.plugin.LoadBalancerPlugin', ] from alembic import op from neutron.db import migration CONSTRAINT_NAME = 'uniq_member0pool_id0address0port' TABLE_NAME = 'members' def upgrade(active_plugins=None, options=None): if not migration.should_run(active_plugins, migration_for_plugins): return op.create_unique_constraint( name=CONSTRAINT_NAME, source=TABLE_NAME, local_cols=['pool_id', 'address', 'protocol_port'] ) def downgrade(active_plugins=None, options=None): if not migration.should_run(active_plugins, migration_for_plugins): return op.drop_constraint( name=CONSTRAINT_NAME, tablename=TABLE_NAME, type='unique' )

commit_message:
Clean up "target" interface to policy

The docstring is wrong for this argument, and we pass an empty
dict since we're not using this data for policy decisions at
the moment, so default it inside common.policy.Enforcer.

Change-Id: I298e691e12ed10825327492f02bd2f4edec24323

subject: Handle '%' in Swift container names.
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-11-08 22:13:42.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/horizon/commit/abf1826a7a33dc8216631695bd0650a5ef834b0b', 'message': 'Handle '%' in Swift container names.

When a Swift container name contains '%', it breaks many URL
leading to an "HTTP 400 Bad request" under Apache.
(Not reproducible with Django development server)

It is due to a Django bug in django.core.urlresolvers.reverse():
"urlresolvers.reverse() generates invalid URLs when an argument contains % character"
https://code.djangoproject.com/ticket/13260
This bug have been fixed in Django 1.6.

django.utils.http.urlquote()

Unit tests have been updated accordingly and
helper functions are now tested.

Closes-Bug: #1231904

commit_message:
Handle '%' in Swift container names.

When a Swift container name contains '%', it breaks many URL
leading to "HTTP 400 Bad request" under Apache.
(Not reproducible with Django development server)

It is due to a Django bug in django.core.urlresolvers.reverse():
"urlresolvers.reverse() generates invalid URLs when an argument contains % character"
https://code.djangoproject.com/ticket/13260
This bug have been fixed in Django 1.6.

In the meanwhile, this patch handles '%' in URL thanks to
django.utils.http.urlquote()

Unit tests have been updated accordingly and
helper functions are now tested.

Change-Id: Ifbe781f66458df0bd013dc935f55ad0ac2c5ac61
Closes-Bug: #1231904
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/02/55702/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # '%' can break URL if not properly quoted (bug 1231904) container_dict_1 = {"name": u"container_one%\u6346", container_dict_2 = {"name": u"container_two%\u6346", object_dict = {"name": u"test_object%\u6346",
deleted_lines: container_dict_1 = {"name": u"container_one\u6346", container_dict_2 = {"name": u"container_two\u6346", object_dict = {"name": u"test_object\u6346",

commit_message:
Add API input validation framework

This patch adds a core part of API validation framework.
Other patches of each API schema are necessary.

The validation method is implemented with jsonschema library,
and some features are added:
 * validate minimum/maximum value of string number(ex. "10")
 * validate uuid string format

This framework can validate requests of both JSON and XML,
because of validating data after JSON/XML deserialization.

The API schema files for Nova v3 API will be created under
nova/api/openstack/compute/schemas/v3. For preparing these
files, this patch adds some __init__.py files.

blueprint nova-api-validation-fw

Change-Id: Ieba96718264ad2ddfba63b65425f7e5bbb8606a9

commit_message:
Pin iso8601 to >=0.1.4 for compatibility with Grizzly

Grizzly stable Glance requires iso8601<=0.1.4, so we need to add this
limit to pass jenkins tests.

Change-Id: I1b5089c6a953ebd36aef4917f65321fc059e2722
Closes-bug: 1255419

commit_message:
powervm: remove powervm virt driver from nova

IBM's strategic direction for OpenStack powervm support
is to support powervc, and therefore support is being
pulled out for the existing powervm IVM/VIOS driver.

DocImpact

Change-Id: I9b7887c1914def145e87cf20dbd0ec65cb0fe987

subject: Adds remote docker registry support
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-11-19 15:27:55.000000000', 'files': ['etc/nova/nova.conf.sample', 'nova/virt/docker/driver.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/1500291dc695f36c5e278a4e002ad4444312446e', 'message': '    Adds remote docker registry support

    The Docker container manager uses its own registry service to manage
    docker containers and docker repositories.  Initial implementation
    assumed that registry service was on the same node as the container.
    This commit allows the Nova administrator to indicate a single IP
    for the centralized Docker registry by adding the optional config
    variable: registry_default_ip to nova.conf.  This is an optional
    variable, and it defaults to 127.0.0.1, which satisfies the original
    authors intended use case.

    Closes-Bug: #1248387

Change-Id: I8592bde1617e9fd826a2b3c91cb315ed35d096f4
'}]
commit_message:
Adds remote docker registry support

    The Docker container manager uses its own registry service to manage
    docker containers and docker repositories.  Initial implementation
    assumed that registry service was on the same node as the container.
    This commit allows the Nova administrator to indicate a single IP
    for the centralized Docker registry by adding the optional config
    variable: registry_default_ip to nova.conf.  This is an optional
    variable, and it defaults to 127.0.0.1, which satisfies the original
    authors intended use case.

    Closes-Bug: #1248387

Change-Id: I8592bde1617e9fd826a2b3c91cb315ed35d096f4

commit_message:
Taskflow persistence

Store task flow persistence in DB, this allow creation of API (in
progress) that will provide execution information like progress.

This patch now in progress, it's early version for community review.

Implemments blueprint: backend-activity

Change-Id: Ie1c80c44f01eb8e19c14d5f638ce4167fc7f416b

Update glance/openstack/common from oslo Part 2

Update from oslo:
- glance/openstack/common/crypto/
- glance/openstack/common/rpc/
- glance/openstack/common/sslutils.py

And update openstack-common.conf

Oslo commit: 764ad35e89d20008bf48d17e4129cfce5b717a6c

Change-Id: I98ab6708c812be1f0b3e52b3d7df660172384d0c

added_lines: # vim: tabstop=4 shiftwidth=4 softtabstop=4 # Copyright 2011-2013 Cloudscaling Group, Inc # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. """ The MatchMaker classes should except a Topic or Fanout exchange key and return keys for direct exchanges, per (approximate) AMQP parlance. """ import itertools import json from oslo.config import cfg from glance.openstack.common.gettextutils import _ # noqa from glance.openstack.common import log as logging from glance.openstack.common.rpc import matchmaker as mm matchmaker_opts = [ # Matchmaker ring file cfg.StrOpt('ringfile', deprecated_name='matchmaker_ringfile', deprecated_group='DEFAULT', default='/etc/oslo/matchmaker_ring.json', help='Matchmaker ring file (JSON)'), ] CONF = cfg.CONF CONF.register_opts(matchmaker_opts, 'matchmaker_ring') LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) class RingExchange(mm.Exchange): """Match Maker where hosts are loaded from a static JSON formatted file. __init__ takes optional ring dictionary argument, otherwise loads the ringfile from CONF.mathcmaker_ringfile. """ def __init__(self, ring=None): super(RingExchange, self).__init__() if ring: self.ring = ring else: fh = open(CONF.matchmaker_ring.ringfile, 'r') self.ring = json.load(fh) fh.close() self.ring0 = {} for k in self.ring.keys(): self.ring0[k] = itertools.cycle(self.ring[k]) def _ring_has(self, key): return key in self.ring0 class RoundRobinRingExchange(RingExchange): """A Topic Exchange based on a hashmap.""" def __init__(self, ring=None): super(RoundRobinRingExchange, self).__init__(ring) def run(self, key): if not self._ring_has(key): LOG.warn( _("No key defining hosts for topic '%s', " "see ringfile") % (key, ) ) return [] host = next(self.ring0[key]) return [(key + '.' + host, host)] class FanoutRingExchange(RingExchange): """Fanout Exchange based on a hashmap.""" def __init__(self, ring=None): super(FanoutRingExchange, self).__init__(ring) def run(self, key): # Assume starts with "fanout~", strip it for lookup. nkey = key.split('fanout~')[1:][0] if not self._ring_has(nkey): LOG.warn( _("No key defining hosts for topic '%s', " "see ringfile") % (nkey, ) ) return [] return map(lambda x: (key + '.' + x, x), self.ring[nkey]) class MatchMakerRing(mm.MatchMakerBase): """Match Maker where hosts are loaded from a static hashmap.""" def __init__(self, ring=None): super(MatchMakerRing, self).__init__() self.add_binding(mm.FanoutBinding(), FanoutRingExchange(ring)) self.add_binding(mm.DirectBinding(), mm.DirectExchange()) self.add_binding(mm.TopicBinding(), RoundRobinRingExchange(ring))

commit_message:
Verify X-Timestamp matches on-disk file name

Verify that the metadata X-Timestamp value is properly normalized
before storage in the file using that timestamp in its name, and that
the retrieved timestamp attribute matches the name of the file from
which it is read.

Change-Id: I66c49d69ad2906a73a92b8533411f303ccf9bbf5
Signed-off-by: Peter Portante <peter.portante@redhat.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/98/44098/18 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if timestamp != metadata['X-Timestamp']: raise ValueError("X-Timestamp metadata not valid.") data_file, meta_file, ts_file = self._get_ondisk_file() if ts_file: assert data_file is None assert meta_file is None self._construct_from_ts(ts_file) if not data_file: assert meta_file is None assert ts_file is None return fp = self._construct_from_data(data_file, meta_file) if keep_data_fp: self.fp = fp else: fp.close() try: mname = self.metadata['name'] except KeyError: pass else: if mname != self.name: def _get_ondisk_file(self): files = sorted(os.listdir(self.datadir), reverse=True) ts_file = None data_file = None meta_file = None for afile in files: if afile.endswith('.ts'): # If we see a tombstone file, it must be the case that we have # not seen a .data file, otherwise we would have exited this # loop. It is possible to have seen a metadata file, which # represents the case of a fast-POST operation successfully # writing data after a concurrent DELETE operation succeeds. assert data_file is None meta_file = None ts_file = join(self.datadir, afile) break if afile.endswith('.meta') and not meta_file: # if we see a metadata file, it must be the case that we have # not seen a .data file or a tombstone file, since that would # have caused this loop to exit. It is possible to have # multiple metadata files before we encounter a data or # tombstone file, so once we see the first .meta file we just # ignore the rest. assert data_file is None assert meta_file is None meta_file = join(self.datadir, afile) # NOTE: this does not exit this loop, since a fast-POST # operation just updates metadata, writing one or more .meta # files, the data file will have an older timestamp, so we # keep looking. if afile.endswith('.data'): assert data_file is None data_file = join(self.datadir, afile) # Once we see a .data file, this object is live. Note that we # might have already seen a metadata file, but we'll handle # that below. break return data_file, meta_file, ts_file def _construct_from_ts(self, ts_file): """ Finish the construction of the DiskFile object using a timestamp file. We pull the metadata from the timestamp file, verify the timestamp matches the name, and add the 'deleted' metadata. """ with open(ts_file) as mfp: self.metadata = read_metadata(mfp) bname = os.path.basename(ts_file).replace('.ts', '') try: m_x_timestamp = self.metadata['X-Timestamp'] except KeyError: raise DiskFileError( "Missing metadata timestamp on %s" % ts_file) else: if bname != m_x_timestamp: raise DiskFileError("Metadata timestamp, %s, does not" " match file name, %s" % ( m_x_timestamp, bname)) # If the most recent file is a tombstone, this object is # considered deleted. self.metadata['deleted'] = True def _construct_from_data(self, data_file, meta_file): """ Finish the construction of the DiskFile object using a data file, and optional meta file. Both the data file and meta file timestamps are compared against their names. When we have a meta file, we also ensure the system metadata keys from the datafile are added to the metadata read from the meta file. """ self.data_file = data_file fp = open(data_file, 'rb') datafile_metadata = read_metadata(fp) bname = os.path.basename(data_file).replace('.data', '') if bname != datafile_metadata['X-Timestamp']: raise DiskFileError("Metadata timestamp, %s, does not" " match file name, %s" % ( datafile_metadata['X-Timestamp'], data_file)) if meta_file: with open(meta_file) as mfp: self.metadata = read_metadata(mfp) bname = os.path.basename(meta_file).replace('.meta', '') if bname != self.metadata['X-Timestamp']: raise DiskFileError("Metadata timestamp, %s, does not" " match file name, %s" % ( self.metadata['X-Timestamp'], meta_file)) sys_metadata = dict( [(key, val) for key, val in datafile_metadata.iteritems() if key.lower() in DATAFILE_SYSTEM_META]) self.metadata.update(sys_metadata) else: self.metadata = datafile_metadata return fp
deleted_lines: files = sorted(os.listdir(self.datadir), reverse=True) meta_file = None for afile in files: if afile.endswith('.ts'): self.data_file = None with open(join(self.datadir, afile)) as mfp: self.metadata = read_metadata(mfp) self.metadata['deleted'] = True break if afile.endswith('.meta') and not meta_file: meta_file = join(self.datadir, afile) if afile.endswith('.data') and not self.data_file: self.data_file = join(self.datadir, afile) break if not self.data_file: self.fp = open(self.data_file, 'rb') datafile_metadata = read_metadata(self.fp) if not keep_data_fp: self.close(verify_file=False) if meta_file: with open(meta_file) as mfp: self.metadata = read_metadata(mfp) sys_metadata = dict( [(key, val) for key, val in datafile_metadata.iteritems() if key.lower() in DATAFILE_SYSTEM_META]) self.metadata.update(sys_metadata) else: self.metadata = datafile_metadata if 'name' in self.metadata: if self.metadata['name'] != self.name:

subject: Ween the object auditor off of the DiskFile class
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-09-03 03:54:59.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/0d00991a9c578149dafbae2d8ecd2925bfa52c0f', 'message': 'Ween the object auditor off of the DiskFile class

Given we are going in the direction that the DiskFile class is the
abstraction layer for the needs of the REST API layer, it seems that
the auditor should not use the same methods in order to truly
"audit". Instead, only the low-level on-disk file logic for the data
directory is shared, and all other verifications are performed using
direct inspections of the data.

As a result, the auditor performs a few more double checks to make
sure the "name" metadata attribute results in the same object data
file; adds some explicit error checking for quarantinable errors (bad
metadata, name does not hash back to the same data directory, unable
to open the file, unable to fstat the file). However, while the
current code will read the entire file only to find out that it does
not have a stored ETag, this code will skip the reading.

Possible related work:

  * Check that the X-Timestamp metadata value matches the given name
    of the object data file

Change-Id: I224e42d06ac49495a59e965502bcf3f323db1929
Signed-off-by: Peter Portante <peter.portante@redhat.com>
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2013-09-03 19:35:36.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/952697f03e41d2d0d7cb317fd16b31580963fd81', 'message': 'Ween the object auditor off of the DiskFile class

Given we are going in the direction that the DiskFile class is the

"audit". Instead, only the low-level on-disk file logic for the data

As a result, the auditor performs a few more double checks to make
sure the "name" metadata attribute results in the same object data
file; adds some explicit error checking for quarantinable errors (bad
metadata, name does not hash back to the same data directory, unable
to open the file, unable to fstat the file). However, while the
current code will read the entire file only to find out that it does
not have a stored ETag, this code will skip the reading.

Possible related work:

  * Check that the X-Timestamp metadata value matches the given name
    of the object data file

Change-Id: I224e42d06ac49495a59e965502bcf3f323db1929
Signed-off-by: Peter Portante <peter.portante@redhat.com>
'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2013-09-06 03:22:45.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/96389317c088971b6ab0937802580ec92b6f4ce3', 'message': 'Ween the object auditor off of the DiskFile class

Given we are going in the direction that the DiskFile class is the
abstraction layer for the needs of the REST API layer, it seems that
the auditor should not use the same methods in order to truly
"audit". Instead, only the low-level on-disk file logic for the data
directory is shared, and all other verifications are performed using
direct inspections of the data.

As a result, the auditor performs a few more double checks to make
sure the "name" metadata attribute results in the same object data
file; adds some explicit error checking for quarantinable errors (bad
metadata, name does not hash back to the same data directory, unable
to open the file, unable to fstat the file). However, while the
current code will read the entire file only to find out that it does
not have a stored ETag, this code will quarantine an object that is
missing an ETag.

We also use this opportunity to bring the test coverage to 99%.

Possible related work:

  * Check that the X-Timestamp metadata value matches the given name
    of the object data file

Change-Id: I224e42d06ac49495a59e965502bcf3f323db1929
Signed-off-by: Peter Portante <peter.portante@redhat.com>

metadata, name does not hash back to the same data directory, unable
to open the file, unable to fstat the file). However, while the
current code will read the entire file only to find out that it does
not have a stored ETag, this code will quarantine an object that is
missing an ETag.

We also use this opportunity to bring the test coverage to 99%.

Possible related work:

  * Check that the X-Timestamp metadata value matches the given name
    of the object data file

Change-Id: I224e42d06ac49495a59e965502bcf3f323db1929
Signed-off-by: Peter Portante <peter.portante@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Ween the object auditor off of the DiskFile class

Since the DiskFile class is the abstraction layer for the needs of the
REST API layer, it seems that the auditor should not use the same
methods in order to truly "audit". Instead, only the low-level on-disk
file logic for the data directory is shared, and all other
verifications are performed using direct inspections of the data. All
the on-disk logic remains in the diskfile module.

As a result, the auditor performs a few more double checks to make
sure the "name" metadata attribute results in the same object data
file; adds some explicit error checking for quarantinable errors (bad
metadata, name does not hash back to the same data directory, unable
to open the file, unable to fstat the file). However, while the
current code will read the entire file only to find out that it does
not have a stored ETag, this code will quarantine an object that is
missing an ETag.

The diskfile module's get_data_file() function returns the name
triple, account, container and object, even though there are no
immediate consumers of it, as there are external to the swift code
base daemons written that can take advantage of that to also ween
themselves off of the DiskFile class.

We also use this opportunity to bring the test coverage to 99%.

Possible related work:

  * Check that the X-Timestamp metadata value matches the given name
    of the object data file

Change-Id: I224e42d06ac49495a59e965502bcf3f323db1929
Signed-off-by: Peter Portante <peter.portante@redhat.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/87/44787/16 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def get_ondisk_file(datadir): """ Do the work to figure out if the data directory exists, and if so, determine the on-disk files to use. :returns: a tuple of data, meta and ts (tombstone) files, in one of three states: 1. all three are None data directory does not exist, or there are no files in that directory 2. ts_file is not None, data_file is None, meta_file is None object is considered deleted 3. data_file is not None, ts_file is None object exists, and optionally has fast-POST metadata """ data_file = meta_file = ts_file = None try: files = sorted(os.listdir(datadir), reverse=True) except OSError as err: if err.errno != errno.ENOENT: raise # The data directory does not exist, so the object cannot exist. else: for afile in files: assert ts_file is None, "On-disk file search loop" \ " continuing after tombstone, %s, encountered" % ts_file assert data_file is None, "On-disk file search loop" \ " continuing after data file, %s, encountered" % data_file if afile.endswith('.ts'): meta_file = None ts_file = join(datadir, afile) break if afile.endswith('.meta') and not meta_file: meta_file = join(datadir, afile) # NOTE: this does not exit this loop, since a fast-POST # operation just updates metadata, writing one or more # .meta files, the data file will have an older timestamp, # so we keep looking. continue if afile.endswith('.data'): data_file = join(datadir, afile) break assert ((data_file is None and meta_file is None and ts_file is None) or (ts_file is not None and data_file is None and meta_file is None) or (data_file is not None and ts_file is None)), \ "On-disk file search algorithm contract is broken: data_file:" \ " %s, meta_file: %s, ts_file: %s" % (data_file, meta_file, ts_file) return data_file, meta_file, ts_file data_file, meta_file, ts_file = get_ondisk_file(self.datadir)
deleted_lines: data_file, meta_file, ts_file = self._get_ondisk_file() def _get_ondisk_file(self): """ Do the work to figure out if the data directory exists, and if so, determine the on-disk files to use. :returns: a tuple of data, meta and ts (tombstone) files, in one of three states: 1. all three are None data directory does not exist, or there are no files in that directory 2. ts_file is not None, data_file is None, meta_file is None object is considered deleted 3. data_file is not None, ts_file is None object exists, and optionally has fast-POST metadata """ data_file = meta_file = ts_file = None try: files = sorted(os.listdir(self.datadir), reverse=True) except OSError as err: if err.errno != errno.ENOENT: raise # The data directory does not exist, so the object cannot exist. else: for afile in files: assert ts_file is None, "On-disk file search loop" \ " continuing after tombstone, %s, encountered" % ts_file assert data_file is None, "On-disk file search loop" \ " continuing after data file, %s, encountered" % data_file if afile.endswith('.ts'): meta_file = None ts_file = join(self.datadir, afile) break if afile.endswith('.meta') and not meta_file: meta_file = join(self.datadir, afile) # NOTE: this does not exit this loop, since a fast-POST # operation just updates metadata, writing one or more # .meta files, the data file will have an older timestamp, # so we keep looking. continue if afile.endswith('.data'): data_file = join(self.datadir, afile) break assert ((data_file is None and meta_file is None and ts_file is None) or (ts_file is not None and data_file is None and meta_file is None) or (data_file is not None and ts_file is None)), \ "On-disk file search algorithm contract is broken: data_file:" \ " %s, meta_file: %s, ts_file: %s" % (data_file, meta_file, ts_file) return data_file, meta_file, ts_file

commit_message:
Exception during synching routers may delay router cleanup

During the removal of routers, if a router delete causes
an exception, the cleanup of remaining routers may be
delayed.

Bug #1232525

Change-Id: I3a06bf9b5855886be21fed7c739a75e5076aeb12
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/00/49300/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if router_id not in self.router_info: LOG.debug(_('Router %s already deleted or not found.') % router_id) return try: self._router_removed(router_id) self.removed_routers.remove(router_id) except Exception: msg = (_('Error encountered while removing router %s.') % router_id) LOG.exception(msg)
deleted_lines: self._router_removed(router_id) self.removed_routers.remove(router_id)

commit_message:
heatclient is failing if os-auth-token (OS_AUTH_TOKEN) is
provided. With this change, user can provide either auth token
or password with heatclient command line tool (heat).

Fixes: Bug #1248265

Change-Id: I22b6af351dd3a371443f432b04785c706eff8397
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-heatclient refs/changes/99/56999/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if args.os_password: _ksclient = self._get_ksclient(**kwargs)
deleted_lines: _ksclient = self._get_ksclient(**kwargs)

subject: fix live migraiton error for rbd image backend
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-11-15 07:16:03.000000000', 'files': ['nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py', 'nova/virt/driver.py', 'nova/tests/virt/libvirt/fake_libvirt_utils.py', 'nova/compute/manager.py', 'nova/virt/libvirt/utils.py', 'nova/tests/compute/test_compute.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/1d4eba408d87c8f7b07c32e3b6c9ac971dd4c2ee', 'message': 'fix live migraiton error for rbd image backend

Currently live migraiton do not work for instances using rbd image
backend due to no shared storage. In order to fix this problem, I did:

  - add shared storage check mechanism for rbd image backend
  - prepare instance path, console log, kernel and ramdisk before migraiton
  - clean up instance path after migraiton

Closes-bug: 1250751

commit_message:
fix live migraiton error for rbd image backend

Currently live migraiton do not work for instances using rbd image
backend due to no shared storage. In order to fix this problem, I did:

  - add shared storage check mechanism for rbd image backend
  - prepare instance path, console log, kernel and ramdisk before migraiton
  - clean up instance path after migraiton

Closes-bug: 1250751

Change-Id: I6118eb71ace6921244949b186a4151d0a8414eba
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/27/56527/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Default page size configuration for image list

Added a configuration 'glance_default_page_size'
defaulted to 100, to always limit image list call
made to python-glanceclient.

This is to define a page size by default when
user does not specify any, in an image-list
call.

Implements bp default-page-size-for-image-list

Change-Id: I81a421139a5c613eaaa4f2e5f9199ad7f911f95e

commit_message:
Correct InstanceInfoCache's network info update after interface-attach

After run command "nova interface-attach",the instance's network info in InstanceInfoCache need to be updated.
Pervious update will cover the old network info with the new one.

Change-Id: I961b4e54f47f9d3a5ee2a3252ecc46730d06b2a1
Closes-Bug: #1249196

commit_message:
Switch off hairpin, to prevent IPv6 DAD failure

When hairpinning is enabled, ICMPv6 messages that handle
duplicate address detections return to the instance, causing IPv6
SLAAC configuration to fail

http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4862#section-5.4.3

Closes-Bug: #1251235
Change-Id: I65e1d40d33d6291bfd5558c7c346fc5fbf92cc56
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/72/58672/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if utils.is_neutron(): utils.execute('brctl', 'hairpin', br_name, v1_name, 'off', run_as_root=True)

commit_message:
Add test_handle_router_snat_rules_add_rules

Add a unit test to verify that snat rules are added and added in order.
So that it could be refactored without fear next time.

(Sniped from the gate to let fixes get ahead of it)

Change-Id: I7b26df29156f7cfacad9fe74902f438eb16f956c
Closes-Bug: #1222660
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/92/58192/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_handle_router_snat_rules_add_rules(self): agent = l3_agent.L3NATAgent(HOSTNAME, self.conf) ri = l3_agent.RouterInfo(_uuid(), self.conf.root_helper, self.conf.use_namespaces, None) ex_gw_port = {'fixed_ips': [{'ip_address': '192.168.1.4'}]} internal_cidrs = ['10.0.0.0/24'] agent._handle_router_snat_rules(ri, ex_gw_port, internal_cidrs, "iface", "add_rules") nat_rules = map(str, ri.iptables_manager.ipv4['nat'].rules) wrap_name = ri.iptables_manager.wrap_name jump_float_rule = "-A %s-snat -j %s-float-snat" % (wrap_name, wrap_name) internal_net_rule = ("-A %s-snat -s %s -j SNAT --to-source %s") % ( wrap_name, internal_cidrs[0], ex_gw_port['fixed_ips'][0]['ip_address']) self.assertIn(jump_float_rule, nat_rules) self.assertIn(internal_net_rule, nat_rules) self.assertLess(nat_rules.index(jump_float_rule), nat_rules.index(internal_net_rule))

subject: Remove SchedulerDependentManager
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-11-03 05:09:07.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/96357b06716a8f5f7146c4bbc9e9aed4ff58e199', 'message': "Remove SchedulerDependentManager

The update_service_capabilities method of this class has been unused
since it was disabled as a periodic task in commit
674ef05b0ac668e16529a3ddc2b8fe26dc729dad.  The compute manager's update
to a v3 rpc api removed the last references to publishing capabilities,
so this can now be completely removed.

After removing the capabilities bits, the only value left in this class
was providing an instance of the scheduler rpcapi class.  This seemed
like overkill, so I removed this class completely and added the
scheduler rpcapi instance to the compute manager directly.

Related to blueprint rpc-major-version-updates-icehouse

Related to blueprint no-compute-fanout-to-scheduler

Change-Id: I72fd16fc96938a9ea9d509e24319a5273de900a9

commit_message:
Remove SchedulerDependentManager

The update_service_capabilities method of this class has been unused
since it was disabled as a periodic task in commit
674ef05b0ac668e16529a3ddc2b8fe26dc729dad.  The compute manager's update
to a v3 rpc api removed the last references to publishing capabilities,
so this can now be completely removed.

After removing the capabilities bits, the only value left in this class
was providing an instance of the scheduler rpcapi class.  This seemed
like overkill, so I removed this class completely and added the
scheduler rpcapi instance to the compute manager directly.

Related to blueprint rpc-major-version-updates-icehouse

Related to blueprint no-compute-fanout-to-scheduler

Change-Id: I72fd16fc96938a9ea9d509e24319a5273de900a9

commit_message:
Allow FakePower to return node objects power_state

Remove hard coded return from node FakePower.get_power_state.
Modify set_power_state to change node objects power state.
This patch will allow for deploys with the Fake driver.

Correct issue in conductor manager where it was passing node_id
where drivers were expecting node_obj.

Change-Id: If0911e50c48ad03aa29f4fd708da8f376c823821
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/33/58333/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def get_power_state(self, task, node_uuid): # Return node object's power state return task.node.get('power_state', state.NOSTATE) def set_power_state(self, task, node_uuid, power_state): task.node['power_state'] = power_state
deleted_lines: def get_power_state(self, task, node): return states.NOSTATE def set_power_state(self, task, node, power_state):

commit_message:
Disable selection of undersized flavors for image

Where an image has minimum requirements for RAM or disk, we should
not allow users to select a flavor that does not meet those
requirements only to have the form fail when submitted.

Change-Id: I00667f4ca30a43771eaf3257fd055d3387687658
Fixes: bug 1116122

commit_message:
rst to xml conversion for project devref rst material

this implements for only cinder at this time so that the patch can be reviewed. py code takes
cinder devref rst and converts it to docbook 5.0 xml. a later patch will implement images,
orderedlists, and programlisting tags. 5 cinder xml files and 14 sections are included in the
training guides associate guide book as an example of how the rst content will be used in the
short term. unused/not xi:included rst will be either be used with other training guides books,
rst patched with updates, and/or patched to be removed from devref source.
Updated to exclude hidden file and remove "&" char.
Removed unicode char. I will need to patch cinder/.../devref as well.

backport:none

implements bp/rst-xml-conversion

Change-Id: I090ff372a1e841ff06e2dec8d45ade74f5cdf5c8
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/43/54643/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?> <section xmlns="http://docbook.org/ns/docbook" xmlns:xi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XInclude" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" version="5.0" xml:id="jenkins"> <title>Jenkins</title> <section xml:id="header"> <title>Header</title> <para> </para> </section> <section xml:id="Continuous-Integration-with-Jenkins"> <title>Continuous-Integration-With-Jenkins</title> <para> =================================== Cinder uses a `Jenkins`_ server to automate development tasks. The Jenkins front-end is at http://jenkins.openstack.org. You must have an account on `Launchpad`_ to be able to access the OpenStack Jenkins site. Jenkins performs tasks such as: `gate-cinder-unittests`_ Run unit tests on proposed code changes that have been reviewed. `gate-cinder-pep8`_ Run PEP8 checks on proposed code changes that have been reviewed. `gate-cinder-merge`_ Merge reviewed code into the git repository. `cinder-coverage`_ Calculate test coverage metrics. `cinder-docs`_ Build this documentation and push it to http://cinder.openstack.org. `cinder-tarball`_ Do ``python setup.py sdist`` to create a tarball of the cinder code and upload it to http://cinder.openstack.org/tarballs .. _Jenkins: http://jenkins-ci.org .. _Launchpad: http://launchpad.net .. _gate-cinder-merge: https://jenkins.openstack.org/view/Cinder/job/gate-cinder-merge .. _gate-cinder-pep8: https://jenkins.openstack.org/view/Cinder/job/gate-cinder-pep8 .. _gate-cinder-unittests: https://jenkins.openstack.org/view/Cinder/job/gate-cinder-unittests .. _cinder-coverage: https://jenkins.openstack.org/view/Cinder/job/cinder-coverage .. _cinder-docs: https://jenkins.openstack.org/view/Cinder/job/cinder-docs .. _cinder-pylint: https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/cinder-pylint </para> </section> </section>

commit_message:
Add warning about GRO and Neutron routers

Generic Receive Offload appears to be enabled by default on recent Ubuntu
kernels. It can have a significant impact on download performance when
enabled on a Neutron router interface. This patch warns users about that.

Change-Id: I3d3a560b1db55aabd901f27ad5c7bd5777b300da
Closes-bug: 1252900
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/06/58606/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: <warning os="ubuntu"> <para>Generic Receive Offload (GRO) should not be enabled on this interface as it can cause severe performance problems. It can be disabled with the ethtool utility. </para> </warning>

commit_message:
Fixed quotes in _assert_tables() method

We suppose, that for some reason we need double-quotes around the
some table names (see change id Id93283905256247bdd2663b799d41a7925804542)
but there is also can be normal case, when we have table names without quotes

Related to blueprint db-use-oslo-common-code

Change-Id: I834cafc6796d517d731c3324fff5008c08b31f7a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance refs/changes/98/57698/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Adding bar chart

Adding charts due to the latest overview wireframes

- Adding reusable bar-chart library
- Adding support of bar-chart to linechart, so there
  can be combination line-bart chart.

Implements blueprint horizon-reusable-charts

Change-Id: I1c0eb891e396ad2c2a309dadee9bf6896db9430e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/97/56997/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Logging user out after self password change

Admin users where not logged out after changing their own password in the user
settings pannel, and error messages where displayed afterwards.

Fixes bug 1226829

Change-Id: Iec0e34484e2bbc28a300d6259aab1a682e4a00ff

commit_message:
Adds domain level support for tasks

Includes:-
  - Domain Task class
  - Domain TaskFactory class
  - DB TaskRepo class
  - Necessary proxy classes for all of the above
  - Tasks related exceptions
  - Unit tests as applicable

Partially implement blueprint async-glance-workers

Change-Id: I619224bcc55b62303f3539454649528f2edc6e9d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance refs/changes/98/54198/20 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2013 IBM Corp. class Task(object): def __init__(self, base, image_repo_proxy_class=None, image_repo_proxy_kwargs=None): self.base = base self.helper = Helper(image_repo_proxy_class, image_repo_proxy_kwargs) task_id = _proxy('base', 'task_id') type = _proxy('base', 'type') status = _proxy('base', 'status') input = _proxy('base', 'input') result = _proxy('base', 'result') owner = _proxy('base', 'owner') message = _proxy('base', 'message') expires_at = _proxy('base', 'expires_at') created_at = _proxy('base', 'created_at') updated_at = _proxy('base', 'updated_at') def run(self, executor): raise NotImplementedError() def kill(self): raise NotImplementedError() def success(self, result): self.base.success(result) def fail(self, message): self.base.fail(message) class TaskFactory(object): def __init__(self, base, proxy_class=None, proxy_kwargs=None): self.helper = Helper(proxy_class, proxy_kwargs) self.base = base def new_task(self, context, task): t = self.base.new_task(context, task) return self.helper.proxy(t)

subject: Shorten PKI token logging
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-11-20 21:09:09.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/devstack/commit/9012787ad89c44f79447a335143579356892ffe0', 'message': "Bump node and conn timeouts, fix PKI token logging

Bump the node and connection timeouts for the swift proxy server so
that on devstack environments with constrained resources we don't get
as many timeouts for successful operations.

We also log only the first 12 characters of auth-token for the Swift
API, since PKI based auth-tokens from keystone can huge (>> 2K).

Also tidy up a comment.

Change-Id: Ib784e8ecdcb7e371fe03458c7fd82b4460fa82b9
Related-Bug: #1252514
Signed-off-by: Peter Portante <peter.portante@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Shorten PKI token logging

Log only the first 12 characters of auth-token for the Swift
API, since PKI based auth-tokens from keystone can huge (>> 2K).

Also tidy up a comment.

Change-Id: Ib784e8ecdcb7e371fe03458c7fd82b4460fa82b9
Signed-off-by: Peter Portante <peter.portante@redhat.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/26/57526/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # The node_timeout determines how long the proxy server will wait for the # next read operation to a backend server (object, container, or account) # to complete, or how long to wait for a response. By raising this up from # the default of 10 seconds (at the time of this commit), resource # constrained object/container/account server processes will have a little # more time to respond. # # The downside to raising this higher than the default (and conn_timeout # below) is that it might take longer to for a gate job to fail. iniset ${SWIFT_CONFIG_PROXY_SERVER} app:proxy-server node_timeout 120 # The conn_timeout determines how long the proxy server will wait for a # backend server (object, container or account) to complete a TCP # connection request (literally, how long a connect() system call is # allowed to take). iniset ${SWIFT_CONFIG_PROXY_SERVER} app:proxy-server conn_timeout 20 # PKI tokens can be huge, seemingly larger the 2K, at the least. Swift # does currently logs the auth-token, and by default just logs the entire # token. We restrict it here to 12 characters, which should be enough to # trace through the logs for its use. iniset ${SWIFT_CONFIG_PROXY_SERVER} filter:proxy-logging reveal_sensitive_prefix 12 # This function generates an object/container/account configuration
deleted_lines: # This function generates an object/account/proxy configuration

added_lines: Keystone Style Commandments =========================== - Step 1: Read the OpenStack Style Commandments http://docs.openstack.org/developer/hacking/ - Step 2: Read on Exceptions ---------- When dealing with exceptions from underlying libraries, translate those exceptions to an instance or subclass of ClientException. ======= Testing ======= python-keystoneclient uses testtools and testr for its unittest suite and its test runner. Basic workflow around our use of tox and testr can be found at http://wiki.openstack.org/testr. If you'd like to learn more in depth: https://testtools.readthedocs.org/ https://testrepository.readthedocs.org/

commit_message:
Use common db model class from Oslo

Modified common model class - added common `models.ModelBase` and
`models.TimestampMixin` classes as base class instead of object.
Renamed base model class from `ModelBase` to `GlanceBase`.
Removed duplicated code.

blueprint db-use-oslo-common-code

Change-Id: I6038adcfcb6b985736ac8d9374ac0a2fe1cdcc96

commit_message:
Use 204 instead of 202 for delete of keypairs v3

The delete of keypairs will access db directly. It isn't async call.
So correct it to return 204.

Closes-bug: 1252169
DocImpact

Change-Id: Ie36c16e1773fa7f61b22bd6735342c7308c7ba35

commit_message:
Rename instance_type parameter in migrate_disk_and_power_off to flavor

Renames the 'instance_type' parameter in the nova virt driver's
migrate_disk_and_power_off method to 'flavor' and handles the immediate
related code changes, i.e. the method itself, the implementations in the
various virt drivers, the tests, and anything called solely from
migrate_disk_and_power_off. This patch does not adjust for everything
that calls into migrate_disk_and_power_off, like from the nova compute
manager code.  That will be handled in a later patch in the series.

Part of blueprint flavor-instance-type-dedup

Change-Id: I47f2b9f6597556dca632d94f83cc1428ad73ae74
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/83/58383/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Dump all log errors and special-case neutron

Also removed neutron whitelist entries since it is not maintained.
neutron will always return 0 for now.

commit_message:
Remove compute 2.x rpc api

A previous change adding support for the 3.x rpc interface but retained
compatibility with 2.x as a transition point.  This commit removes the
old API from the server side.

The object_compat decorator is unused as of this commit.  However, I'm
leaving it, because it's going to start getting used very soon again as
more of the compute rpc api gets updated to accept Instance objects.

UpgradeImpact

Part of blueprint rpc-major-version-updates-icehouse

Change-Id: I31c21055163e94b712d337568b16b9b7a224b52f

commit_message:
Add v3 of compute rpc API

Add support for the 3.0 compute rpc API.  This commit retains compatibility
with the older 2.X API to allow continuous deployment without any downtime.

The v3 rev of this API was determined primarily by copying the current API
in nova.compute.rpcapi.  That class always reflects the latest rev of the
API that is actually being used.

UpgradeImpact - Deployments doing continuous deployment should follow this
process to upgrade without any downtime with the consoleauth service:

1) Set [upgrade_levels] compute=havana in your config.

2) Upgrade to this commit.

3) Once everything has been upgraded, remove the entry in
[upgrade_levels] so that all rpc clients to the nova-compute service
start sending the new 3.0 messages.

Part of blueprint rpc-major-version-updates-icehouse

Change-Id: I5d303445ded2342a54d8319b79df172ce50fa716

commit_message:
docker: return hypervisor_version as an int rather than a string

The compute_nodes.hypervisor_version type in the database is an integer
so the docker driver needs to return the hypervisor_version as an
integer rather than a string.

Also adds the missing unit test for get_available_resource.

Closes-Bug: #1253960

Change-Id: I4e2ac13f9203b54e71f1f5cd8e15311921dd85c5

commit_message:
Fixed urls import

"from django.conf.urls.defaults" is deprecated in django 1.5 (and does not work
with django 1.6)

fixed import

Change-Id: I7a0f63de2b4c0f9fffe2c3ba6062fdd8a35ab111
Closes-Bug: #1251248

deleted_lines: from django.conf.urls.defaults import patterns, include, url

commit_message:
Move flag in libvirt's vif to the libvirt group

This change continues moving libvirt specific flags into a libvirt
specific configuration group.

Progresses blueprint libvirt-opts-group.

DocImpact: the following flag has been moved into the libvirt
group:
    use_virtio_for_bridges (formerly libvirt_use_virtio_for_bridges)

Change-Id: I755139f0a470a091e36760836c9200f15aa72c37

commit_message:
Move flag in libvirt's utils to the libvirt group

This change continues moving libvirt specific flags into a libvirt
specific configuration group.

Progresses blueprint libvirt-opts-group.

DocImpact: the following flag is now in the libvirt group:
    snapshot_compression (formerly libvirt_snapshot_compression)

Change-Id: I9eddec5cdb72a1313e044a3c7c6d75e8ad34533a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/97/55497/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: cfg.BoolOpt('snapshot_compression', 'currently applies exclusively to qcow2 images', deprecated_group='DEFAULT'),CONF.register_opts(libvirt_opts, 'libvirt') if CONF.libvirt.snapshot_compression and dest_fmt == "qcow2":
deleted_lines: cfg.BoolOpt('libvirt_snapshot_compression', 'currently applies exclusively to qcow2 images'),CONF.register_opts(libvirt_opts) if CONF.libvirt_snapshot_compression and dest_fmt == "qcow2":
